Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: not notary nodes

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: well to be more accurate, notary nodes validate a block just like any other regular network nodes

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: the network nodes having a full copy of blockchain on their machine

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: how does the notarization knows it was not manipulated by an attack?

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: I mean the notary nodes, how do they know

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content:
if you the regular user have the bitcoin wallet with full blockchain on your machine.
and there is a double spend tx happened, you understand how that block with invalidate tx is invalidated?

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: it is based on verifying the data from local synchronised database and the data coming from the network  validated by a miner

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: if a early block had the same tx spent, it invalidates the new double spend tx

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: yes, and in case someone has more then 50% manipulated blockchain copys?

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: it is the usual satoshi consensus

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: the addition what dPoW adds to that is it adds a consensus rule of making it *impossible* to reorg the block height past the notarised block

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: if for example a last block known to be notarised is 2 blocks ago

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: the only time span is the time between the next notarised block you can plan and try any kind of 51% attack

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: not so sufficient time

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: you can only manipulate the last 10 Minutes that still are not notarized, yes, that I know

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: but what prevents that a new manipulated block gets through?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you are confused

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you are assuming there is an "evil" block and a "good" block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but there is only valid blocks and invalid blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it is valid, it is valid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: regardless of who mines it, if a block is valid, it is valid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once it is notarized, then it is prevented from being overwritten, even if there is a longer (otherwise valid) chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if an attacker is secret mining what he hopes to be the longer chain that double spends, the moment a height is notarized that is after the start of his secret chain, his secret chain is no longer considered

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the public chain is what gets notarized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as the notaries can only see blocks that are public

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: yes I may be confused, but I got that part, that the past blocks cannot be altered anymore if protected by dPoW. What I still not get 100% is, what prevents the notary nodes to be manipulated and to add a valid block, but some that was manipulated (is that posssible?)

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: @tobias what matters isn't that a block is 'good' or 'evil' according to miner's intentions, it matters only that it can't be overwritten. An attacker can produce as many blocks as he wishes but, unless he can overwrite a previous block, there's no actual attack taking place!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: assuming you corrupt the majority of notaries, you could make them make up any sort of invalid notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which would then be IGNORED by all the nodes, that are validating all notarizations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries that are not corrupted only notarize valid blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but regardless, ALL nodes (miners,wallets, etc) are validating ALL notarizations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so in a majority notary corrupted scenario, you cant prevent the wrong block from being notarized, but it wont have any effect as it is an invalid block and ignored by the rest of the network

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: ok, but what happens to the notarized history then, if the last wrong block is already in the BTC chain as well and is ignored? Is it pulled then? I cannot imagine how it works as the blocks are nested.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: invalid notarizations are IGNORED

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what part of that is confusing?

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: the last sentence you wrote I understood, that it could theoretical happen that a wrong block gets into the BTC chain via dPoW, or did I misunderstand?

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: and I understood, that it would not be a problem, because that wrong block would be ignored then

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: or did you mean it different?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in the EXTREMELY unlikely event a wrong block gets into the BTC chain, it is IGNORED

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: yes, ok

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: that I udnerstand

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW protects even against the extremely unlikely

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and all nodes validate

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: yes, I believe that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the only trust given to notaries are to differentiate between valid blockhashes and selecting the notarized chain

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: and how can the blocks be ignored? by skipping? and the next block notarized is referring to the current block - 2  ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but the normal consensus rules are always running and notarizations are crosschecking against that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if a notarization is ignored, it is exactly like it didnt happen at all

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ignore, as in pretend it doesnt exist

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: so it reffers to current block - 2

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what referal?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you are assuming things that dont exist, are somehow existing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nodes check for valid notarizations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if they see one, they update the notarized height

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dont overcomplicate it

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: I thought that blocks are referred to the last block before

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
nodes check for valid notarizations
if they see one, they update the notarized height

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: ok, maybe I got it. So nodes are going through all the notarized blocks and those who are wrong are ignored, right? I mean, if someday that even would happen

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a notarization is a normal transaction

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as a new block comes in, it is scanned for a valid notarization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: by valid notarization, that means it is a valid block already in that nodes blockchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it sees such a notarization, it updates its state to have a new notarized height

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the other thing it does is that if it sees a block trying to overwrite a notarized block, it rejects it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is all that it does

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 99.9% it is the same as normal consensus for the chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no magic

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just scanning for valid notarizations and updating the current notarized height

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if there is any magic, it is in the creation of the notarized tx, but the NN take care of that

Author: Tobias Nunes#4493
Content: ok, thank you, I think I understood it now.

Author: richardt#2807
Content: Just a thought:  Komodo could have a technology demonstration for more people to understand how the security mechanism works.  Create a test blockchain with dPOW enabled and try to 51% attack it and see what happens.  Has this been done before?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @richardt it's happened to EMC2 by an attacker pre-announcing the attack, and also Hush DPoW was recently tested by KMD people, to verify it works correctly. And it did 😃

Author: richardt#2807
Content: Nice.  It would be pretty amazing for KMD if ETC decides to go with dPOW to secure itself.  It seems to me they're at a dead-end and need some kind of solution fast or people will stop trusting it altogether.

Author: Instel7#1416
Content: @richardt EMC2 has already recommended them to implement it 🙂 https://twitter.com/einsteiniumcoin/status/1082593492646404096
